trial_identification.studytitle: Research on equivalence of high blood pressure diagnosed by conventional medicine and traditional Chinese medicine
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Morbidity research of traditional Chinese medicine patterns as related to conventional medicine diseases: An observational study on systemic arterial hypertension

interventions.interventions: Subjects will be assessed by an interviewer for evaluation of specific symptoms of systemic arterial hypertension related to traditional Chinese medicine. Each patient will be interviewed once during approximately 30 minutes. Overall duration of this study is 1 year.
interventions.comparator: Results will be compared to diagnosis made by conventional medicine practitioners on high blood pressure. The diagnostic criteria of systemic arterial hypertension are systolic and diastolic arterial blood pressure equal to, or higher than, 140 and 90 mmHg, respectively, measured in two or more consecutive visits at the outpatient clinic over a period of at least 7 days. Brachial systolic and diastolic blood pressures will be measured on the right arm with a mercury column sphygmomanometer. Each visit will last approximately 20 minutes.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Morbidity of traditional Chinese medicine patterns related to systemic arterial hypertension. Demographic and clinical data (age, systolic pressure, diastolic pressure, mean blood pressure, pulse pressure, heart rate, and body mass index) are presented as mean and standard deviation (SD) according to hypertension-related pattern subgroups.
Frequency of manifestations (signs and symptoms) related to high blood pressure obtained from the questionnaires. Descriptive statistics will be used to asses the reults.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Statistical correlation among clinical variables and manifestations.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Clinical diagnosis of systemic arterial hypertension.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Presence of comorbidities such as diabetes and kidney failure.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Systemic arterial hypertension is the leading risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Its diagnosis is based on repetitive blood pressure evaluations. Traditional Chinese medicine reports that diagnosis is based on manifestations (i.e., signs & symptoms) and no other measure is needed to diagnose a subject. The aim of this work is to evaluate possible associations between conventional medice and traditional Chinese medicine in identifying subjects high blood pressure.
